channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Exploding Pagers Targeting Hezbollah Kill 11 and Wound Thousands
item.description: The Iranian-backed militant group, which uses pagers to safeguard communications, blamed Israel for the attacks in Lebanon. Israel declined to comment.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Euan Ward, Ronen Bergman and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: After hundreds of pagers exploded across Lebanon, the wounded were rushed to hospitals in ambulances, like this one in Beirut, on Tuesday.

item.title: Second Apparent Assassination Attempt on Trump Prompts International Alarm
item.description: There is widespread concern that the November election will not end well and that American democracy has frayed to the breaking point.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump speaking onstage during the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee in July as a photograph of the aftermath of an assassination attempt was emblazoned on a screen.

item.title: Ukraine-Russia War Updates: Moscow Hits Back in Kursk as Air War Heats Up
item.description: Moscow’s troops have retaken a few villages in a border area that Kyiv’s forces invaded last month and are also advancing steadily in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Haley Willis
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on the move in an armored vehicle in the Donetsk region on Sunday.

item.title: With Sandbags and Team Spirit, a Polish City Fought Off a Flood
item.description: Thousands of residents of Nysa, in southern Poland, formed a human chain overnight to pass each other sandbags, building a wall along a river embankment to keep the raging waters at bay.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Anatol Magdziarz
item.media:description: Local residents pile up sandbags to protect the embankment of the Nysa Klodzka River against the floods in Nysa, southern Poland.

item.title: Israel’s Netanyahu Considers Firing Defense Minister Gallant in Government Shakeup
item.description: Dismissing the minister, Yoav Gallant, would remove a frequent critic of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at a time of mounting tensions with Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, left, and Defense Minister Yoav Gallant at a news conference in Tel Aviv in October.

item.title: Dominique Pelicot, Husband on Trial for Drugging and Raping Wife, Testifies
item.description: Dominique Pelicot, who is accused of inviting strangers to rape his wife while she was drugged and unconscious, took the stand for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Gisèle Pelicot, center, the ex-wife of Dominique Pelicot, arriving at the Avignon courthouse with her lawyers on Tuesday.

item.title: Burning Oil Tanker in Red Sea Is Towed to Safety
item.description: The delicate rescue mission aimed to head off a major environmental disaster after the oil tanker was attacked by Houthi rebels off the coast of Yemen last month.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: The oil tanker Sounion in the Red Sea on Saturday. It has since been towed to safety.

item.title: Hamas Plans Future in Gaza After Surviving Israel’s Onslaught
item.description: Khaled Meshal, one of Hamas’s most senior officials, said in an interview that the militant group expects to play a decisive role in the enclave when the war is over.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: People walking on a street in Khan Younis, in the south of the Gaza Strip, on Sunday.

item.title: Manchester City’s Premier League Hearing, Explained
item.description: The world’s richest soccer league accused its champion of years of financial violations. A hearing that began this week could tarnish the club’s accomplishments and reshape the competition.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: The charges date back to 2009, a year after Manchester City’s purchase by the brother of the ruler of Abu Dhabi. That acquisition began a turbocharged era of spending — and success.

item.title: What to Know About the France Rape Trial of 51 Men
item.description: Prosecutors say that, for almost a decade, Dominique Pelicot drugged his wife to rape her, alongside dozens of other men he invited to abuse her.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Gisèle Pelicot, 71, arriving at court in Avignon, France, in September to testify against her former husband.

item.title: Trudeau’s Liberal Party Loses Parliament Seat in Montreal Special Election
item.description: The election in Montreal had been seen as a referendum on Canada’s deeply unpopular prime minister, who has faced calls from within his party to quit.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s approval ratings have stagnated just above 20 percent for the past year.

item.title: What Is JNIM, the Al Qaeda Affiliate Claiming Attacks in Mali?
item.description: An extremist group that claims allegiance to Al Qaeda said it was responsible for assaults on a military police school and an air base in the West African country of Mali.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: Smoking rising in the distance behind crowds in Bamako, Mali, on Tuesday after an attack. The violence could raise questions about the security strategy of the country’s military leaders.

item.title: Von der Leyen Doles Out Top E.U. Jobs
item.description: Ursula von der Leyen named her choices for the European Commission as she navigates a host of challenges, including the rise of nationalist forces.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Union’s executive arm, presented its new leaders on Tuesday in Strasbourg, France.

item.title: Death Toll Rises as Deadly Floods Threaten Central Europe: What We Know
item.description: At least 17 people have died and thousands have been displaced. “Relief is not expected to come before tomorrow, and more likely, the day after,” an official in Austria said.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: An aerial picture of the flooded town of Klodzko, southwestern Poland, on Sunday.

item.title: Gold Apollo Says It Didn’t Make Pagers Used in Lebanon Attack
item.description: The company, Gold Apollo, said it had not manufactured the devices, pointing to another company that it said was licensed to use its brand.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers at the Gold Apollo factory in Taipei, Taiwan, on Wednesday.

item.title: Europe’s Floods Are Another Sign of Growing Threat of Climate Change
item.description: Climate change is influencing extreme weather events like the flooding across six European countries that has led to mass evacuations of cities as the waters continue to rise.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney
item.media:description: Rescue workers evacuating flooded areas in Ostrava, Czech Republic, on Monday.

item.title: U.N. Sees ‘Human Rights Abyss’ in Myanmar as Military Kills Civilians
item.description: Three years after the military staged a coup, intensifying a civil war, civilians continue to pay the price, according to a coming United Nations report.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers from an armed insurgent group in Myanmar walked through a church damaged by the military in southern Karenni State in January.

item.title: Cathy Merrick, Advocate for Indigenous People in Canada, Dies at 63
item.description: She was on the front lines of dogged fights against injustices, including a recent series of murders of Indigenous women by a white man.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Kim Wheeler

item.title: Israel Planted Explosives in Pagers Sold to Hezbollah, Officials Say
item.description: Small amounts of explosive were implanted in beepers that Hezbollah had ordered from a Taiwanese company, according to American and other officials briefed on the operation.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Ronen Bergman

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Exploding Pagers Kill at Least 9 in Lebanon
item.description: Plus, China’s “silver economy.”
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Lebanese army soldiers in the streets of Beirut yesterday.

item.title: Biden Administration Extends Review Period for Nippon Takeover of U.S. Steel
item.description: U.S. Steel’s chief, David Burritt, expressed confidence on Tuesday that the sale of the American manufacturer to a Japanese owner would close “on its merits” despite bipartisan backlash.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: David Burritt, chief executive of U.S. Steel, has warned that the company could lay off workers and relocate its headquarters outside Pennsylvania if the deal were blocked.

item.title: A Look at Israel-Hezbollah Tensions and How a Wider War Could Impact Lebanon
item.description: Hezbollah and Israel have repeatedly traded strikes since the Gaza war began in October, killing civilians and combatants in Lebanon and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah fighters at the funeral of a commander in August, in the southern suburbs of Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: $50 Billion in Aid to Ukraine Stalls Over Legal Questions
item.description: U.S. and European officials are struggling to honor their pledge to use Russian assets to aid Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukraine’s leader, and President Biden held a news conference during the Group of 7 Summit in Savelletri, Italy, in June.

item.title: Portugal Going Through ‘Difficult Days’ as Wildfires Burn Across the Country
item.description: More than 5,000 personnel are battling a number of wildfires, the authorities said, and the prime minister called it an “extremely difficult weather situation.”
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: A helicopter dropped water to try to contain a fire in Albergaria-a-Velha, Portugal, on Monday.

item.title: Meta Plans to Ban the Russian TV Network RT
item.description: The owner of Facebook and Instagram said it would bar Russian media outlets including RT, while YouTube is removing channels it had already blocked.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Meta, which owns Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp, said the ban would take place in the coming days.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Suspect is Charged in Apparent Trump Shooting Attempt
item.description: Plus, why you should binge “Shogun.”
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roads to Donald Trump’s golf club in West Palm Beach, Fla., were closed off yesterday.

item.title: Thierry Breton, Top E.U. Commissioner, Resigns, Citing ‘Questionable Governance’
item.description: The surprise resignation of Thierry Breton came after he accused Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, of pressuring France to nominate another candidate instead of him for commissioner.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, and Thierry Breton, France’s European Union commissioner, meeting in Brussels in June.

item.title: Brazilian Politician Upends Debate by Hitting Opponent With Chair
item.description: The stunning attack on live television is likely to reorder the race to lead São Paulo, Latin America’s largest city.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Ana Ionova
item.media:description: Mr. Marçal, at a campaign event earlier this month, has shaped his political style in the mold of other brazen right-wing leaders like Donald J. Trump and former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro.

item.title: Russia Ramps Up Air Assault on Ukrainian Cities
item.description: An attack on Kyiv early Monday was the eighth on the Ukrainian capital in about two weeks, officials said, adding that most of the incoming Russian drones had been intercepted.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: A Ukrainian police officer helping a civilian leave the site of a missile attack in Kharkiv on Sunday.

item.title: In Georgia, a Political Uproar Erupts Over a 2008 War With Russia
item.description: The leader of the governing party said the country should apologize for a conflict for which many Georgians blame Moscow, heightening a monthslong political battle.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: The founder of the governing Georgian Dream party, Bidzina Ivanishvili, center, during a rally in support of a bill on “foreign agents” in April.

item.title: China Frees American Pastor, David Lin, After Nearly 20 Years in Prison
item.description: David Lin had tried to open a Christian training center in Beijing. The United States considered him one of three Americans “wrongfully detained” by China.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: How Rituals of Faith Became Another Casualty of War
item.dc:creator: Sergey Ponomarev and Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Marking major holidays has been completely upended for three religions this year. For Palestinians in the West Bank, restrictions have limited access to holy sites.

item.title: Israeli Defense Minister Tells U.S. Military Action Against Hezbollah Is Needed
item.description: Meeting with a senior Biden administration adviser, Defense Minister Yoav Gallant said “the only way” for Israel to return its displaced citizens to the northern border is through military action against Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: Smoke billows from the site of an Israeli airstrike that targeted southern Lebanon on Sunday.

item.title: Shanghai is Hit By Typhoon Bebinca, Strongest Storm in 70 Years
item.description: The city canceled all flights at its two airports and closed major attractions, amid a three-day national holiday.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Typhoon Bebinca, which logged winds around 94 miles per hour near its center, felled trees and billboards in Shanghai.

item.title: In Linda Sun’s Case, Signs of a Familiar China Playbook
item.description: Linda Sun is just the latest member of the Chinese diaspora whom Beijing is accused of recruiting to influence Western democracies.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.category: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China
item.media:description: Linda Sun, a former senior aide in the New York governor’s office, with her husband after being charged with acting as an agent for China.

item.title: Mexico’s Contentious Judiciary Overhaul Becomes Law
item.description: Going forward, Mexican voters will now elect judges at every level, dramatically restructuring the third branch of government.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Mexico City on Tuesday night.

item.title: Morning Briefing: The Fallout of Trump’s False Claims
item.description: Plus, Ye performs in China.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Michael Ciaglo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dilapidated buildings in Aurora, Colo., are at the center of a national firestorm fueled by Donald Trump’s anti-immigration claims.

item.title: 3 Hostages Likely Killed by Israeli Strike Last Fall, I.D.F. Says
item.description: An inquiry into the deaths of three Israeli hostages determined that they probably died as a result of a military airstrike targeting a Hamas commander.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier posting a photograph of Ron Sherman, one of the hostages mistakenly killed by Israeli soldiers in the Gaza Strip, in November.

item.title: Floods Kill More Than 1,000 People in West and Central Africa
item.description: Flooding caused by heavy rains has left more than 1,000 people dead and hundreds of thousands of homes destroyed.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Ismail Alfa
item.media:description: Partly submerged houses after a dam overflowed in Maiduguri, Nigeria, on Tuesday.

item.title: Houthis Launch Missile at Central Israel
item.description: The rare attack was an illustration of the evolving conflict in the Middle East between Israel and Iranian proxies.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: A police officer inspecting the area around a fire after the Israeli military said it tried to intercept a missile launched from Yemen on Sunday.

item.title: An Era of Chinese Adoption Ends, and Families Are Torn Over Its Legacy
item.description: More than 80,000 children from China were adopted by American families. While many appreciate how the adoptions reshaped their own lives, they are also glad to see the program conclude.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amy Cubbage, left, and Graham Troop looking through the adoption trip albums from when they traveled to China in 2008 to adopt their daughter, June.

item.title: Despite Relentless Russian Attack, Life in Kharkiv Endures Underground
item.description: Kharkiv, Ukraine, has adjusted to life amid the threat of bombings. Its resilience is manifested in a curious blend of life above and below ground.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Berehulak, Constant Méheut and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn
item.media:description: Despite constant bombings, residents of Kharkiv, Ukraine, have found opportunities for joy and emotional release.

item.title: How a Tourist Paradise Became a Drug-Trafficking Magnet
item.description: Costa Rica’s lush rainforests, which blanket a quarter of the country, are being infiltrated by cartels on a quest to find new trafficking routes to evade the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Alejandro Cegarra
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Costa Rican Border Police agents patrolling in a tropical forest in Sierpe, Costa Rica.

item.title: Why is Ye, Formerly Kanye West, Doing a Show in China?
item.description: The provocative artist once known as Kanye West has received approval that was denied to Maroon 5 and Bon Jovi. China’s economic woes might be why.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Ye onstage in Inglewood, Calif., in March.

item.title: Going the Distance at the Tram Driver Olympics
item.description: Europe’s public transit captains showed off their skills at an annual championship. “We have been practicing,” a Dutch competitor said. “But the other teams have also been practicing, too.”
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: The European Tramdriver Championship, now in its 11th year, brought competitors from across Europe to Frankfurt on Saturday.

item.title: Once Considered Foes, Iranian-Backed Groups Get a Warm Welcome From Iraq
item.description: Hamas and the Houthis have opened offices in Baghdad, reflecting the two groups’ evolving relationship with Iraq as Tehran works to build a regional power bloc.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:description: A crowd chanted slogans and waved Palestinian flags in Baghdad last month to show support for Palestinians in Gaza.

item.title: Paris Throws a Final Olympics Bash
item.description: Tens of thousands cheered, clapped, danced and sang to celebrate French athletes and to relive, one last time, the Games that uplifted a nation.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Crowds roared, waved flags and sang France’s national anthem as more than 300 French Olympic and Paralympic contestants were honored on Saturday in Paris.

item.title: Divided Attention
item.description: On the eve of the Emmy Awards, it’s worth taking a look at what we’re actually watching.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Churchill, Abducted From Canada, Is Found Glowering in Italy
item.description: The theft of an iconic Churchill portrait by Yousuf Karsh went unnoticed for months. But two years later, the police have tracked down the photograph.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: A forged copy of Yousuf Karsh’s portrait of Winston Churchill hanging at the Fairmont Château Laurier in April 2022.

item.title: At Funeral in Turkey, Family Mourns American Activist Aysenur Eygi
item.description: The father of Aysenur Ezgi Eygi, a dual citizen of Turkey and the United States, said that Washington had not done enough to pressure Israel over her death.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
item.media:credit: Bradley Secker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Turkish security forces carried the coffin of Aysenur Ezgi Eygi during her funeral at the central mosque in Didim, in western Turkey, on Saturday.

item.title: Shoes Off. Laptops Out. Airport Tray Photo Shoot?
item.description: A new social media trend involves creatively arranging your T.S.A. bins, and showing them off.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses and Remy Tumin

item.title: As Ukraine Presses Its Attack in Kursk, Russia Stiffens Its Defenses
item.description: Soldiers and military analysts say that Ukraine is largely holding onto land it seized in the Kursk region, even as Moscow has begun a counterattack.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and David Guttenfelder
item.media:description: Digging through the wreckage of a home after a missile strike on a neighborhood in Sumy, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Amazon Sought Tariff Loophole Used by Chinese Rivals. Now Biden Is Closing It.
item.description: Under pressure from Chinese competitors, Amazon, Walmart and other U.S. retailers have been exploring ways to avoid tariffs. Could a new Biden administration rule change that?
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Jordyn Holman
item.media:credit: Octavio Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amazon has been preparing a new discount service that would ship products directly to consumers, allowing those goods to bypass tariffs.

item.title: A Year After a Deadly Flood, a Libyan City Is Rebuilding but Not Whole
item.description: Derna is quickly being reconstructed after a flood that killed thousands. But questions linger about the process, and residents say new buildings cannot erase their trauma.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: One of the new bridges under construction in Derna, Libya.

item.title: Election in Montreal Poses a Test for Trudeau
item.description: A vote in Montreal is seen as a referendum on Canada’s prime minister, who has brushed aside calls to step down as party members fear a wipeout in the next general election.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau during a visit to Montreal in 2022. His popularity has plunged.

item.title: The Long-Range Weapons Ukraine Wants to Use on Russia, Explained
item.description: The United States and its allies are once again considering expanding the capabilities they provide to Ukraine in its fight against Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson and Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: John Hamilton/White Sands Missile Range, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Army Tactical Missile Systems, known as ATACMS, have a range of 190 miles.

item.title: Paraguay Loves Mickey, the Cartoon Mouse. Disney Doesn’t.
item.description: Mickey, a homegrown food-packaging company, is famous for facing down Disney in Paraguay’s Supreme Court. As the family business turns 90, why is it still so popular?
item.dc:creator: Laurence Blair and María Magdalena Arréllaga
item.media:credit: María Magdalena Arréllaga for The New York Times

item.title: Sexual Abuse Allegations Against Abbé Pierre Shatter His Legacy
item.description: Abbé Pierre campaigned for decades against homelessness and poverty. Revelations about his treatment of women have destroyed his image as a symbol of virtue in France.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: An image of Abbé Pierre at a charity shop in 2020 run by one of the social justice organizations he founded.

item.title: Sweeping Iraq Raid Killed 4 ISIS Leaders
item.description: The U.S. military said those killed in a joint assault by U.S. and Iraqi forces last month included the group’s top commander in Iraq and its leading bomb maker.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Members of an Iraqi counterterrorism force during a military exercise in Baghdad last year. The United States and other allied forces have helped Iraqi forces carry out more than 250 counterterrorism missions since October.
